Operators

John Mount, Nina Zumel

2019-03-26

Source: vignettes/operators.Rmd
operators.Rmd

As of cdata version 1.0.8 cdata implements an operator notation for data transform.

The idea is simple, yet powerful.

First let’s start with some data.


d <- wrapr::build_frame(
  "id", "measure", "value" |
    1   , "AUC"    , 0.7     |
    1   , "R2"     , 0.4     |
    2   , "AUC"    , 0.8     |
    2   , "R2"     , 0.5     )

knitr::kable(d)
id measure value
1 AUC 0.7
1 R2 0.4
2 AUC 0.8
2 R2 0.5

In the above data we have two measurements each for two individuals (individuals identified by the “id” column). Using cdata’s new_record_spec() method we can capture a description of this record structure.

library("cdata")

record_spec <- new_record_spec(
  wrapr::build_frame(
    "measure", "value" |
    "AUC"    , "AUC" |
    "R2"     , "R2"  ),
  recordKeys = "id")

print(record_spec)
#> $controlTable
#>   measure value
#> 1     AUC   AUC
#> 2      R2    R2
#> 
#> $recordKeys
#> [1] "id"
#> 
#> $controlTableKeys
#> [1] "measure"
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "cdata_record_spec"

Once we have this specification we can transform the data using operator notation.

We can collect the record blocks into rows by a “factor-out” (or aggregation/projection) step.

knitr::kable(d)
id measure value
1 AUC 0.7
1 R2 0.4
2 AUC 0.8
2 R2 0.5 

d2 <- d %//% record_spec

knitr::kable(d2)
id AUC R2
1 0.7 0.4
2 0.8 0.5

We can expand record rows into blocks by a “multiplication” (or join) step.

knitr::kable(d2)
id AUC R2
1 0.7 0.4
2 0.8 0.5 

d3 <- d2 %**% record_spec

knitr::kable(d3)
id measure value
1 AUC 0.7
1 R2 0.4
2 AUC 0.8
2 R2 0.5

We also have an order sensitive %pivot% operator. Record specification on the right multiplies into blocks and record specification on the left factors into row records.

record_spec %pivot% d %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id AUC R2
1 0.7 0.4
2 0.8 0.5 

# identity
( record_spec %pivot% d ) %pivot% record_spec %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id measure value
1 AUC 0.7
1 R2 0.4
2 AUC 0.8
2 R2 0.5 

# identity
record_spec %pivot% d %pivot% record_spec %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id measure value
1 AUC 0.7
1 R2 0.4
2 AUC 0.8
2 R2 0.5 


# identity
record_spec %pivot% ( d2 %pivot% record_spec ) %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id AUC R2
1 0.7 0.4
2 0.8 0.5

We can also pipe into the spec (and into its adjoint).

# reverse or adjoint/transpose operation specification
t_record_spec <- t(record_spec)

d %.>% 
  t_record_spec %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id AUC R2
1 0.7 0.4
2 0.8 0.5 

# using dot-pipe's bquote style .() execute immediate notation
d %.>% 
  .(t(record_spec)) %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id AUC R2
1 0.7 0.4
2 0.8 0.5 

# identity
d %.>% 
  .(t(record_spec)) %.>% 
  record_spec %.>%
  knitr::kable(.)
id measure value
1 AUC 0.7
1 R2 0.4
2 AUC 0.8
2 R2 0.5

And that is truly fluid data manipulation.

Developed by John Mount, Nina Zumel.
